name: battery management system production, for Li-ion battery | battery management system, for Li-ion battery | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24752/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of Battery Managment System (BMS), which is part of the Li-ion battery pack. The BMS is modelled according to the publication of Ellingsen et al. (2014). See technology comment for further details. ;Reference:;Ellingsen, L. A. W., Majeau‐Bettez, G., Singh, B., Srivastava, A. K., Valøen, L. O., & Strømman, A. H. (2014). Life cycle assessment of a lithium‐ion battery vehicle pack. Journal of Industrial Ecology, 18(1), 113-124.

The activity starts when the battery module boards, the integrated battery interface system, the low and the high voltage systems enter the factory.

The activity ends with the production of the battery management system at the factory gate.
category: C:Manufacturing/27:Manufacture of electrical equipment/272:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators/2720:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2014 (year of the publication of data) and 2020 (year of the dataset)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Original data were provided by the battery producer Miljøbil Grenland, located in Norway, for a Li-ion battery for use in electric vehicles. (Ellingsen et al. 2014, Life cycle assessment of a lithium‐ion battery vehicle pack. Journal of Industrial Ecology, 18(1), 113-124). This dataset can be considered representative of the global production of battery management systems. Geography uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The battery management system is an electronic component in a lithium-ion battery. It includes battery module boards (BMB), the integrated battery interface system (IBIS) and fasteners, high voltage (HV) system, and low voltage system. BMB are placed under module lids, situated between two rows of busbars and their functions is to monitor the battery cells for voltage and temperature limits, whereas the IBIS acts as a master controller for the BMB.
